title: Age-Adjusted D-dimer for Venous Thromboembolism (VTE)
description: Adjusts D-dimer cutoffs to help rule out VTE in patients ≥50 years old, improving specificity while maintaining sensitivity

parameters.name: age
parameters.description: Patient age in years (must be ≥50 years old)

parameters.name: d_dimer_unit_type
parameters.description: Type of D-dimer units used by the laboratory

parameters.name: d_dimer_level
parameters.description: Measured D-dimer level (optional, for comparison with cutoff)

ranges.interpretation: If measured D-dimer ≤ cutoff: VTE diagnosis unlikely, no further testing needed. If measured D-dimer > cutoff: VTE cannot be ruled out, proceed with imaging (CTA or V/Q scan).

references: Schouten HJ, Geersing GJ, Koek HL, et al. Diagnostic accuracy of conventional or age adjusted D-dimer cut-off values in older patients with suspected venous thromboembolism: systematic review and meta-analysis. BMJ. 2013;346:f2492.
Righini M, Van Es J, Den Exter PL, et al. Age-adjusted D-dimer cutoff levels to rule out pulmonary embolism: the ADJUST-PE study. JAMA. 2014;311(11):1117-1124.

Sharp AL, Vinson DR, Alamshaw F, Handler J, Gould MK. An Age-Adjusted D-dimer Threshold for Emergency Department Patients With Suspected Pulmonary Embolus: Accuracy and Clinical Implications. Ann Emerg Med. 2016;67(2):249-257.
formula: FEU: Age × 10 µg/L; DDU: Age × 5 µg/L
notes: Only applicable to patients ≥50 years old
More specific than conventional D-dimer cutoffs with minimal reduction in sensitivity
FEU (Fibrinogen Equivalent Units) is more common, with conventional cutoff ~500 µg/L
DDU (D-dimer Units) is less common, with conventional cutoff ~250 µg/L
Not appropriate for high-risk patients who should proceed to imaging regardless
Should be used in conjunction with clinical probability assessment
Age-adjusted cutoffs help prevent unnecessary imaging in elderly patients
D-dimer alone cannot confirm VTE diagnosis - imaging is required for confirmation
